hedline.hl1: When Art Goes Over the Line

abstract.p: Michael Schneider letter on March 2 article says art is not intended to be pleasant or soothing

block.p: We see Holocaust pictures from time to time, and they are very unpleasant reminders of past events and conditions, but we remain safely behind the insulating shields of time and shallow distractions.
Artists' creations are not intended to be pleasant or soothing. Nor are they shallow, ridiculous or foolish! They are art functioning as it can and should -- provoking thought and strong feeling.
We see Holocaust pictures from time to time, and they are very unpleasant reminders of past events and conditions, but we remain safely behind the insulating shields of time and shallow distractions.
Artists' creations are not intended to be pleasant or soothing. Nor are they shallow, ridiculous or foolish! They are art functioning as it can and should -- provoking thought and strong feeling.
Alan Schechner's composition ''It's the Real Thing: Self-Portrait at Buchenwald'' is the real thing (news article, March 2). Such art is a powerful gift from a bold and talented artist to the world.
MICHAEL SCHNEIDER Atlantic Highlands, N.J. March 2, 2002
